facts.text: Appellant is the landlord and respondent is a protected tenant.
Appellant gave notice of termination of tenancy to respondent on December 31, 1951, under s. 34(1) of the Act, for one year, tenancy to terminate after March 31, 1953.
Landlord made application on April 7, 1953, under s. 29(2) of the Act to Mamlatdar for possession of the land.

Amendment to the Act by insertion of sub-s. (2-A) to s. 34 by Amending Act No. XXXIII of 1952, came into force on January 12, 1953, placing further restrictions on landlord's right to terminate tenancy of protected tenant.
Tenant objected to application claiming benefit of third clause of sub-s. (2-A).
Mamlatdar allowed landlord's application under s. 29(2).
Tenant's appeal to higher authority dismissed.
Tenant's revision to Revenue Tribunal rejected.
Tenant filed application under Art. 227 of Constitution before Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2258 of 1955.

Bombay High Court allowed tenant's application on January 9, 1956, relying on Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai, holding Amending Act applies as tenancy terminated after it came into force.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 34(2-A) of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, introduced by Amending Act No. XXXIII of 1952 effective January 12, 1953, applies to notices of termination given before the amendment but where tenancy terminates after the amendment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice given in December 1951 before Amending Act; right to terminate tenancy arises on date of notice under s. 34(1), so further limitations in sub-s. (2-A) do not apply to notices given before amendment.
Law applicable is that existing on date of notice; applying sub-s. (2-A) would take away vested right of landlord.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions of s. 34(2-A) should be considered; revenue courts erred in not applying it as tenancy terminated and right to possession accrued after Amending Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 34(2-A); Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaverbhai Bhikabhai

respondent_arguments.text: Amending Act applies to proceedings where notice period expired after it came into force; imposes new limitation on right to obtain possession.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-s. (2-A) imposes restrictions on right to terminate tenancy; crucial date is date tenancy terminates (after notice expires), not date of notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice under s. 34(1) is mere declaration of intention; right to terminate perfects on termination date.

court_reasoning.text: No vested right accrues until tenancy terminates; Amending Act applies if in force before termination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amending Act fetters right of termination without affecting prior vested rights.

court_reasoning.text: Amending Act is beneficent legislation for tenant protection; doubt resolved in tenant's favour.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-s. (2-A) applies to cases where tenancy not terminated before Amending Act.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Jeebankrishna case as circumstances different; here period of notice unchanged, issue is application date of new restrictions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Crucial date is termination, not notice.

holdings.text: S. 34(2-A) applies to all cases where notices given but tenancy not terminated before Amending Act came into force.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on it to hold Amending Act applies if tenancy terminated after it; SC agrees view correct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jeebankrishna Chakrabarti v. Abdul Kader Chaudhuri
precedents_cited.relevance: Different circumstances; amendment changed notice period, unlike here where period same and issue is termination date.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, No. LXVII of 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs termination of tenancy by landlord; sub-s. (2-A) imposes restrictions on right to terminate protected tenancy, applicable on termination date.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands (Amendment) Act, No. XXXIII of 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced further restrictions on landlord's right to terminate; beneficent for tenants.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tenant filed application before High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds Bombay High Court's view correct that s. 34(2-A) applies as tenancy terminated after Amending Act; appeal by landlord dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Tenant entitled to protection under s. 34(2-A)

key_quotes.text: The restriction by sub-s. (2-A) is on the right to terminate the tenancy and this restriction would come into play on the day on which the landlord's right to terminate the tenancy is perfected, namely, the day on which the tenancy actually terminates.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines crucial date for application of sub-s. (2-A)

key_quotes.text: The Amending Act is a piece of beneficent legislation meant for the protection of tenants. Therefore, if there is any doubt about the meaning of sub-s. (2-A) that doubt should be resolved in favour of the tenant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
